question.text: If f(x) = <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="" open="{" separators="|"><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>λ</mi><msqrt><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></msqrt><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>μ</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12,</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mn>3</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>9</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mfenced></math> is differentiable at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, then the value of <math><mi>λ</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>μ</mi></math> is equal to

solution.text:
∵f(x) is continuous at x=3

∴LHL=RHL=f(3)

λ2(3)+3=μ(3)+12 ⇒λ=μ+4 ......(1)

Also f(x) is differentiable at x=3

∴ at x=3 LHD=RHD

λ22(3)+3·2=μ⇒λ=3μ ......(2)

By (1) and (2)

μ=2,λ=6

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced open="{" close="" separators="|"><mrow><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mo>:</mo><mfenced open="|" close="|" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>≥</mo><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>α</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>β</mi></mtd><mtd><mo>:</mo><mfenced open="|" close="|" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>.</mo></mrow></mfenced></math> If <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is continuous and differentiable at any point, then

solution.text:
The given function is clearly continuous at all points except possibly at x=±1.
For fx to be continuous at x=1, we must have
limx→1-fx=limx→1+fx=f1
⇒limx→1-αx2+β=limx→1+1x2
⇒α+β=1 … 1
Now, for fx to be differentiable at x=1, we must have
limx→1-fx-f1x-1=limx→1+fx-f1x-1
⇒limx→1-αx2+β-1x-1=limx→1+1x2-1x-1 ∵α+β=1∴β-1=-α
⇒limx→1-αx2-αx-1=limx→1+1x2-1x-1
⇒limx→1-αx+1=limx→1+-2x3⇒2α=-2
⇒α=-1
Putting α=-1 in 1, we get β=2

question.text: If <math> <mrow> <mi>f</mi><mfenced> <mi>x</mi> </mfenced><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mfenced close="" open="{"> <mrow> <mtable equalcolumns="true" equalrows="true"> <mtr> <mtd> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msqrt> <mrow> <mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow> </msqrt> <mo>−</mo><mo> </mo><msqrt> <mrow> <mn>4</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow> </msqrt> </mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mfrac> <mo>,</mo></mrow> </mtd> <mtd> <mrow> <mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow> </mtd> </mtr> <mtr> <mtd> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow> <mrow> <mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow> </mfrac> <mo>,</mo></mrow> </mtd> <mtd> <mrow> <mn>0</mn><mo> </mo><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo><mo>≤</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow> </mtd> </mtr> </mtable></mrow> </mfenced></mrow> </math> is continuous in <math> <mrow> <mrow><mo>[</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mo>],</mo></mrow> </mrow> </math> then the value of <math> <mi>a</mi> </math> is

solution.text:
Given that fx is continuous in the interval [-1, 1], so, it will be continuous at x=0.

Now f0+= -14

f0-= limx →0-⁡2axx (4+ax + 4-ax ) (rationalizing)

= limx→0-⁡2a4=a2

Now f0+=f(0-) (∵ f(x) is continuous at point 0)

⇒    a2=-14 ⇒   a=-12

question.text: The value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mfenced><mn>0</mn></mfenced></math> so that the function <math> <mrow> <mtext>f</mtext> <mfenced close=")" open="(" separators=","> <mrow> <mtext>x</mtext> </mrow> </mfenced> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>-</mo> <mtext>cos</mtext> <mfenced close=")" open="(" separators=","> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>-</mo> <mtext>cos </mtext> <mtext>x</mtext> </mrow> </mfenced> </mrow> <mrow> <msup> <mtext>x</mtext> <mn>4</mn> </msup> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </math> is continuous everywhere is <math><mtext>k</mtext></math>, then value of <math> <mrow> <mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>k</mtext></mrow> </math> is

solution.text:
If fx is continuous at x=0

fx= lim x → 0 f x

      = lim x → 0 1 - cos 1 - cos  x x 4 × 1 + cos 1 - cos  x 1 + cos 1 - cos  x

       = lim x → 0 sin 2 1 - cos  x x 4 · 1 + cos 1 - cos  x · 1 - cos  x 2 1 - cos  x 2

       = lim x → 0  sin 1 - cos  x 1 - cos  x 2 × lim x → 0 1 - cos  x x 2 2 × lim x → 0 1 1 + cos 1 - cos  x

       = 1 2 × 1 4 × 1 2 = 1 8

∴ k= 1 8 ⇒10 k= 5 4 =1.25

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced open="{" close="" separators="|"><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><mfenced><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>cos</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></mfenced><mfenced><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>sin</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></mfenced></mtd><mtd><mo>:</mo></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>λ</mi></mtd><mtd><mo>:</mo></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mfenced></math> is continuous at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>,</mo></math> then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>λ</mi></math> is equal to

solution.text:
For the function fx to be continuous at x=2π

limx→2πfx=f2π

Now, limx→2π1-cosx2π-x2sin2xlog1+2π-x2=λ

Putting x=2π+t, we get, 

limt→01-costt2⋅sin2tlog1+t2=λ

limt→012⋅sin2tt2⋅t2log1+t2=λ

12×1×1=λ

⇒λ=12

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="" open="{" separators="|"><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mo>:</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>:</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mfenced></math> (where <math><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mfenced></math> denotes the greatest integer function), then

solution.text:
fx=ex+x-1x+xx≠0-1x=0
limx→0-fx=limx→0-ex+x-1x+x=e-1-1-1=e-1e
limx→0+fx=limx→0+ex+x-1x+x=limx→0+ex-1x=1
∵LHL≠RHL at x=0⇒fx is discontinuous at x=0

question.text: Let <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="" open="{" separators="|"><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">sin</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>l</mi></mrow><mrow><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">sin</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msup><mo>,</mo></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">tan</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">tan</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msup><mo>,</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>m</mi><mo>,</mo></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mfenced></math> is continuous at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Then, the values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>l</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math> are

solution.text:
We have,
limh→0+⁡f0-h=limh→0+⁡1+sin⁡-hlsin⁡-h
=limh→0+⁡1+sin⁡hlsin⁡h
=limh→0+⁡1+sin⁡h1sin⁡hl=el
limh→0+⁡f0+h=limh→0+⁡etan⁡2htan⁡3h
=elimh→0+⁡tan⁡2h2h×23×3htan⁡3h=e1×23×1=e23

Also, f0=m
For fx to be continuous at x=0, we must have
limh→0+⁡f0-h=limh→0+⁡f0+h=f0⇒el=e23=m
⇒l=23 and m=e23

question.text: The function <math> <mrow> <mtext>f</mtext> <mfenced close=")" open="(" separators=","> <mrow> <mtext>x</mtext> </mrow> </mfenced> <mo>=</mo> <mfenced close="}" open="{" separators=","> <mrow> <mtext>x</mtext> </mrow> </mfenced> <mtext> sin </mtext> <mfenced close=")" open="(" separators=","> <mrow> <mi>π</mi> <mfenced close="]" open="[" separators=","> <mrow> <mtext>x</mtext> </mrow> </mfenced> </mrow> </mfenced> </mrow> </math>, where [.] denotes the greatest integer function and {.} is the fractional part function, is discontinuous at

options.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></math> which is not an integer

solution.text:
f x = x  sin  π x

=xsin (integral multiple of π )

= 0

Hence, f(x) is continuous for all x.

question.text: The function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><munder><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></munder><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>π</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced open="[" close="]" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> is (where, <math><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mfenced></math> denotes the greatest integer function and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>N</mi></math>)

solution.text:
fx=limn→∞cos2πxn+x

=x:cos2πx∈0,11+x:cos2πx=1
=x:x∉Ι1+x:x∈Ι
For x=1,
f1-=1-=0, f1+=1+=1, f1=1+1=2
∵f1+≠f1-⇒fx is discontinuous at x=1
For x=32,

f32+=32+=1, f32-=32-=1, f32=32=1
∵f32-=f32+=f32
⇒fx is continuous at x=32

question.text: Let <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=-</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>,</mo></math> where <math><mi>p</mi></math> is a real number. If <math><mi>g</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math> and <math><mi>g</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is discontinuous at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>,</mo></math> then <math><mi>p</mi></math> cannot be (where <math><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mfenced></math> represents the greatest integer function)

solution.text:
fx=-x-122+p+14
If gx is discontinuous at x=12, then f12 should be an integer.

Hence, p cannot be 12

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mfenced close="}" open="{" separators="|"><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="}" open="{" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="}" open="{" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mfenced close="}" open="{" separators="|"><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mo>∀</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mn>0,10</mn></mfenced></math> (where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mo>·</mo></mfenced></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="}" open="{" separators="|"><mo>·</mo></mfenced></math> are the greatest integer and fractional part functions respectively). The number of points of discontinuity of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> is

solution.text:
fx=xx2+x2+xx2+x2
=x+xx2+x2
=x.x2=x3
Hence, fx is continuous ∀x∈0,10

question.text:
Consider function fx=tan{2x-3}x-2,  x∈(2,∞)x2+sgn(x),x∈(-∞,2], then at x=2

[Note: {k} & [k] denote fractional part & greatest integer function less than or equal to k respectively and sgn denotes signum part of function.]

solution.text:
L.H.L.=limh→0 (2−h)2+sgn2−h

=3+1=4

f(2)=4+1=5
∴fx is discontinuous.

question.text: Given <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="" open="{"><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><msqrt><mn>10</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt></mtd><mtd><mtext> if </mtext><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mtd><mtd><mtext> if </mtext><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mfenced></math> The graph of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is -

solution.text:
f'3+=limh→0f(3+h)-f(3)h
=limh→02-eh-1h=-limh→0eh-1h=-1
f'3-=limh→0f(3-h)-f(3)-h

=limh→010-(3-h)2-1-h=-limh→01+6h-h2-1-h

=limh→06h-h2-h1+6h-h2+1=-62=-3

Hence, f'3+≠f3-

question.text: If <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>, then the points of discontinuity of the function <math><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> where <math><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>f</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mi>o</mi><mi>f</mi></math> (<math><mi>n</mi></math> times) are

solution.text:
Clearly, x=1 is a point of discontinuity of the function fx=11-x.
if x≠1, then
fof x=ffx=f11-x=x-1x, which is discontinuous at x=0.
If x≠0 and x≠1, then
fo fofx=ffofx=fx-1x=x
Which is continuous everywhere.
Hence, f30x=x, which is continuous everywhere.
So, the only points of discontinuity are x=0 and x=1

question.text:
Let f be a composite function of x defined by

fu=1u2+u-2, ux=1x-1.

Then the number of points x where f is discontinuous is :

solution.text:
μx=1x-1, which is discontinous at x=1

fu=1u2+u-2=1u+2u-1

which is discontinous at u=-2, 1

when u=-2, then 1x-1=-2⇒x=12

when u=1, then 1x-1=1⇒x=2

Hence given composite function is discontinous at three points, x=1, 12 and 2 .

question.text: In <math> <mrow> <mrow><mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi> </mrow> <mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, the total number of points where <math><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>.</mo><mfenced close="}" open="{" separators="|"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">sin</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">cos</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>–</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">cos</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is not differentiable, are equal to

solution.text:
The graph of fx=max.sin⁡x,cos⁡x,1–cos⁡x  is



⇒ fx is not differentiable at x= π 4 ,  π 2 ,  5π 3 .
 
⇒ fx is not differentiable at 3 points

question.text: Consider the function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mfenced open="{" close="}" separators="|"><mrow><mfenced open="|" close="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mfenced open="|" close="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mo>∀</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mfenced open="[" close="]" separators="|"><mrow><mn>0,3</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>. If <math><mi>λ</mi></math> is the number of points at which <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is non-differentiable, then the value of <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> is

solution.text:
Using graph of sin⁡x&cos⁡x, we get, 
fx is non differentiable at

x1=π4, x2=3π4, x3=5π4, x4=7π4, x5=9π4, x6=11π4
Hence, λ=6

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>max</mi><mo>.</mo><mfenced close="}" open="{"><mrow><mfenced close="|" open="|"><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>|</mo><mo>|</mo><mo>,</mo><mo>|</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mfenced></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>min</mi><mo>.</mo><mfenced close="}" open="{"><mrow><mfenced close="|" open="|"><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>|</mo><mo>|</mo><mo>,</mo><mo>|</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mfenced></math> then if <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is not differentiable at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>'</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mo>'</mo></math> number of points and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is non differentiable at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>'</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">q</mi><mo>'</mo></math> number of points, then find <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>|</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">q</mi><mo>|</mo></math>.

solution.text: \(\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})\) is not differentiable function at \(x=-3,-1,0,1,3\) \(g(x)\) is not differentialble at \(\mathrm{x}=-3,-2,-1,0,1,2,3\)

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mfenced close="}" open="{" separators="|"><mrow><msqrt><mn>9</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt><mo>,</mo><msqrt><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt></mrow></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mo>∀</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>3,3</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>, then the number of point(s) where <math><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is non-differentiable is/are

solution.text:
Using graph of
y=9-x2⇒x2+y2=9 ,
y=1+x2⇒y2-x2=1
In the figure, we can see the graph of fx

Clearly, fx is non-differentiable at
x=-3, x1, x2, 3 ( 4 points)
because there are sharp points at x1, x2 and at x=3, x=–3 there are vertical tangents.

question.text: Consider a function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>g</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mo>∀</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>,</mo></math> where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="" open="{" separators="|"><mrow><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mo>:</mo></mtd><mtd><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>≥</mo><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></mtd><mtd><mo>:</mo></mtd><mtd><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>.</mo></mrow></mfenced></math> If <math><mi>g</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is continuous as well as differentiable for all <math><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo></math> then

solution.text:
For gx to be continuous and differentiable ∀x∈R, fx must be continuous and differentiable ∀x∈R
Since, f(x) is continuous for all x, therefore, it is continuous at x=1 also.
∴f1=limh→0+f1-h=1=limh→0+a1-h2+b
⇒a+b=1 … 1
Also, fx is differentiable at x=1⇒f'1−=f'1+
⇒limh→0+f1-h-f1-h=limh→0+f1+h-f1h
⇒limh→0+a1-h2+b-1-h=limh→0+11+h-1h
⇒limh→0+a+b-1+h2-2ha-h=limh→0+1-1-hh1+h
⇒2a=-1 Using a+b=1
∴a=-12
Hence, a+b=1⇒b=1-a=32.

question.text:
Let f(x)=[n+psinx],x∈(0,π),n∈I and p is a prime number. The number of points where f( x ) is not differentiable is

( Here x represents the greatest integer less than or equal to x )

solution.text:
fx=n+psinx

As we know the greatest integer function is discontinuous at integer.

So, fx is discontinuous when psinx is integer.

In 0, π2. fx is discontinuous when psinx=1, 2, .......p-1

and in  π2, π, fx is discontinuous when psinx=1, 2, .......p-1

and at π2, psinx=p

So total number of points of discontinuity is p-1+p-1+1=2p-1 

As we know function is not differentiable at a point when function is not continuous at that point.

So total number of point of where fx is not differentiable is 2p-1

question.text: The number of points at which the function <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>0.5</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">tan</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></math> is not differentiable in the interval <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math> is/are

solution.text:
The curve will have sharp corner at x = 0.5 and at x = 1 and a point of discontinuity at x= π 2.
Hence, total number of points where the function is not differentiable is 3.

question.text: Let <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>-</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi></math>, then the set of all values of <math><mi>x</mi></math> at which <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math> is not differentiable is

solution.text:
ffx=10-fx-5=10-10-x-5-5
=10-5-x-5⇒10-x-5-5
Points where ffx is non-differentiable are
x-5=0 & x-5=5
x=5 & x=0,10

question.text: Consider <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="" open="{" separators="|"><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mfenced></math> and <math><mi>g</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math>. Then, in the interval <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>g</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> is

solution.text:
Given, fx=-2,-2≤x<0x2-2,0≤x≤2
∴fx=2,-2≤x<02-x2,  0≤x<2x2-2,2≤x≤2
And fx=x2-2, x∈-2,2
∴gx=x2,-2≤x<00,0≤x<22x2-2,2≤x≤2
g ′ x = 2x −2<x<0 0 0<x< 2 4x 2 <x<2
g'0−=0=g'0+g'2−=0,g'2+=42
So, gx is not differentiable at x=2

question.text: Consider the function <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>, then the incorrect statement is

solution.text:
∵ x-2 & x2-3x+2 both are continuous ∀x∈R
∴fx is continuous ∀x∈R
Now, x2-3x+2=x-1x-2
∴ fx=x-2x-1x-2:x∈-∞,1∪2,∞-x-2x-1x-2:x∈1,2
fx=x-1x-22:x∈-∞,1∪2,∞-x-1x-22:x∈1,2
f'x=x−12x−2+x−22:   x∈−∞,1∪2,∞−x−12x−2−x−22:   x∈1,2
Clearly,  f ′ 2 − =f' 2 + =0⇒f x is differentiable at x=2
and  f ′ 1 − =1, f ′ 1 + =−1⇒f x is non-differentiable at x=1

question.text: The number of points where the function,<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>s</mi><mo>|</mo><mn>2018</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>|</mo><mn>2020</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo><mo>+</mo><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfenced><mfenced open="|" close="|"><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfenced></math> is non-differentiable is/are

solution.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2020</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi></math> are points of non-differentiability

question.text:
Let g(x)=ax2+bx+c(cotx)n4+(cotx)n,  x∈0,π41,   at x=π4sinx+cosx+(tanx)n1+c(tanx)n,  x∈π4,π2, where a, b, c are real constants and 

fx=limn→∞gx If limx→π4fx exists, then c may be equal to

solution.text:
gx=ax2+bxcotxn+c41+4cotxn=c   if   x<π4sinx+cosx+1tanxn1tanxn +c=1c   if   x>π4

limit to exist c=1c⇒c2=1, c=±1

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo> </mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="" open="{"><mtable columnalign="left" columnspacing="1.4ex"><mtr><mtd><mi>min</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>{</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>:</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>}</mo><mo>,</mo></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>]</mo></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>sin</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mi>π</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mfenced></math> then

solution.text:
f(x)=cos x
f'(x)=-sin x<0
So, function is decreasing in x∈[0,π]
gx=f(x),x∈[0,π]sin x-1,x>π
∴L.H.L.=R.H.L.=f(π)=-1.

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> is a differentiable function such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>y</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>∀</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>y</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></mrow><mi>x</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>210</mn></math>, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>2</mn></mfenced></math> is equal to

solution.text:
f'x=limh→0fx+h-fxh

=limh→0fx+fh+2xh-fxh

f'x=limh→0fhh+2x=210+2x

fx=210x+x2+C

f0=0⇒C=0

fx=210x+x2

∴f2=424

question.text: Let <math><mi>f</mi><mi></mi><mo>:</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>R</mi></math> be a function such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>y</mi></mfenced></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mn>0</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math> <mrow> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mfenced> <mn>0</mn> </mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo></mrow> </math> then

solution.text:
We have, fx+y3=fx+fy3,f0=0 and f ′ 0 =5
f ′ x = lim h→0 f x+h −f x h
=limh→0⁡f3x+3h3-f3x+03h
=limh→0f3x+f3h3-f3x+f03h
= lim h→0 f 3h −f 0 3h = f ′ 0 =5
∴fx=5x+c∴f0=0⇒c=0
Hence, fx=5x
